comment._content: Brilliant shot, rule the world with loaves and guns.  Is that a sprinkling of snow on the ground?  Note the sign "Machine made bread"?  The exact opposite to todays boast of hand made everything!

makes one think it is not being transacted properly!!!
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 24830903@N06
comment._content: War is tragic :( My father drove a bread bike in Arnhem during WW2 , he was a baker for 50 years , he didn't speak often of the war except D day xoxo I miss him so much , thank you for sharing this poignantly telling photograph xoxo

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
The jumble of stuff along the background appears to be a street barracade.

How tastes come and go in full circle. The sign exclaims 'machine made bread' and these days we clamour for nostalgia in the form of traditional home-made, hand-made breads!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: New hi-res casts doubt on Kennedy's ID, since the trays in the van are clearly labelled Halligan.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I know they say that hindsight is an exact science but if you look at the side of the van the strokes of the otherwise indecipherable name show upward loops of Halligan rather than the lower letters of Kennedy?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I agree! While I'm sure "stray" trays from various companies were used by delivery men, it just doesn't look like Kennedy's on the side of the van...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I can't find anything online about Halligan's bakery, except a spooferific account of Kevin Barry being arrested there (actually he was at Monks bakery on North King Street/Church Street.) The 1911 census does show a John Halligan, Baker, living in Rialto street, but I don't know if he sold bread under that name.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Possibly the corner of Suffolk Street and Church Lane. The Anti Treaty party had their head-quarters at No 23 Suffolk Street prior to the outbreak of the Civil War.Streetview OSI "On March 22nd 1922 he (Rory O’Connor) invited a number of Pressmen to the headquarters of the Anti-Treaty party in Suffolk Street Dublin and repudiated the Dail which he declared had “done an act which it has no moral right to do.” source. The two lads are not on a footpath so the road maybe wide at this point and Church Lane does slope down to Dame Street. If I'm right Jammets restaurant would once have been behind the van.I dont know when the bank was built but maybe the mullions/columns in the top left of the picture are those in present view? Hard to be certain about location. Maybe Hogan was one of those 'pressmen' and Halligans was delivering bread to Jammets :)......We'll never know!
